job_title: Student Support Officer in London, England
pros: Flexibility Creativity Joyful Great customer service

All staff are friendly and welcoming and there are regular events hosted in the office and outside to help cohesion. Christmas and Summer parties are great and the CEO even takes randomly picked employees out for lunch on the company on a regular basis.

HR and associated committees put so much work into initiatives and opportunities for staff.  Free flu jabs, free telephone counselling, Perkbox and freebies in the staff kitchens are all offered. There is also a big drive to ensure fairness and that everyone’s voices are heard. All policies are reviewed and agreed with input from across the business.

Employees are encouraged to join in and get involved with committees dealing with various subjects across the business and are freely given time out of their working day to go to these meetings. 

Strongly disagree with the review that mentioned mental health is not a priority as there are regular events for this, with many trained MHFA’s in every office. I’ve also had really positive experiences of compassionate and sick leave being needed as well.

London office and campus are set in great locations with stunning views and nice area surrounding them with plenty of places to go for lunch/shopping/walks.
cons: Sometimes projects are very slow to get moving and there can be a very ‘laid back’ culture. While this has its positive sides it can lead to frustrations when you need business critical items on time.

review_title: Archaic culture and repressive middle management
pros: There are some really nice, genuine people working in both offices. The Christmas and summer parties are well-organised by the Social Committee. Okay location in The City.
cons:
Clearly, the previous two reviews have been written by management/HR. 

The culture is very restrictive. The company boasts "flexible" working as a benefit; however, in order to change your contracted work hours by even 30 minutes, one must apply and go through a 6 month trial period concluding with a review (followed by subsequent regular reviews). How is this flexible? 

Regular working from home is also near impossible unless you are management. WFH days for employees are logged on a system and frowned upon by management and HR, despite the proven advantages. You have to beg for a WFH day most of the time. 

Very few opportunities to advance career. High turnover of staff due to unnecessary bureaucracy, low staff morale and unapproachable management. Examples include: 
- Management's and HR's concern when you take sick leave isn't your well-being but the legitimacy of your reason. 
- Polarised management style - they expect all employees to fit the same mould and do not use individuals' strengths to the company's benefit. 
- Some managers really struggle with empathy such as granting compassionate leave (even when signed off by HR). 

LIBF regard themselves as a mental health conscious organisation; however, they are yet to demonstrate this and have no forward-thinking policies in place.
